clinical_study.brief_title: Reliability of Ultrasound Assisted Epidural Analgesia in Obese and Normal Weight Parturients
clinical_study.official_title: Reliability of Ultrasound Assisted Epidural Analgesia in Obese and Normal Weight Parturients

brief_summary.textblock: This study wants to investigate if ultrasound assisted epidural catheter insertion for labor analgesia is easier and safer to the standard epidural technique.

primary_outcome.measure: The congruity between palpatory technique and ultrasound lumbar evaluation
primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 3 days
primary_outcome.description: The congruity between palpatory technique and ultrasound lumbar evaluation to identify the correct spinal space performing epidural analgesia

secondary_outcome.measure: Longitudinal and transverse ultrasound epidural space depth in obese and normal parturients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 3 days
secondary_outcome.description: Longitudinal and transverse ultrasound epidural space depth in obese and normal parturients will be measured and compared to the needle depth

arm_group.description: parturients admitted to the labor ward who request epidural analgesia with BMI < 30
parturients admitted to the labor ward who request epidural analgesia with BMI > 30

study_pop.textblock: all women after thirty weeks of pregnancy, experiencing spontaneous or induced labor

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- all women who request epidural analgesia for labor
Exclusion Criteria:
- all women who present contraindication for epidural analgesia
